sp.p: Here's Florio would fain take his leave; ſo, ſo, ſhe comes.

lg.l: I drew the Weapon to it:
Heaven knows, my Brother lov'd me: Now I hope
The Duke wo'not purſue me with new Flames.
Sciarrha, tell the reſt, love one another
The time you live together: I'll pray for you
In Heaven, farewel, kiſs me when I am dead;
You elſe will ſtay my Journey.
Did'ſt not hear
An Angel call her? Floria, I have much
To tell thee, take her up: She is not dead,
Let her alone; nay then ſhe's gone indeed.
But hereabouts her Soul muſt hover ſtill:
Let's ſpeak to that fair Spirit.
Do you talk wiſely then? An excellent Pattern
As ſhe now ſtands for her own Alablaſter.
Cannot thy Tears and mine preſerve her, Florio?
But we loſe time, I charge thee by thy love
To this pale Relick, be inſtructed by me,
Not to thy danger; ſome revenge muſt be,
And I am loſt already; if thou fall,
Who ſhall ſurvive to give us Funeral?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: I ever was in heart your humbleſt Vaſſal.

lg.l: Th'art faithful, I muſt cheriſh thy deſert,
I ſhortly ſhall reward it, very ſhortly;
Next morning muſt ſalute me Duke; the Sun
And I muſt riſe together.
I ſhall pray
Your Glory may out-ſhine him in your Florence,
And when he ſets, we may enjoy your Sun-beam.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: 'Tis handſom flattery, and becomes a Courtier.

lg.l: Then th'art a Fool:
No Muſick to a Great Man Chimes ſo ſweetly:
And Men muſt thrive; come hither, How many
Haſt thou kill'd▪
And I muſt owe
My Life to your Lordſhip, I had been hang'd elſe.
But one? wait at the Door, he is
Not fit to kill a Duke, whoſe Hand is guilty
But of a ſingle Murder; or at leaſt
Not fit alone to act it: I ha' been
Practis'd already, and though no Man ſee't,
Nor ſcace the Eye of Heaven, yet every day
I kill a Prince; appear thou Tragick Witneſs.
lg.stage: [He diſcovers the Duke's Picture, a Ponyard ſticking in it.
lg.l: Which though it bleed not, I may boaſt a Murder.
Here firſt the Duke was painted to the Life:
But with this Pencil to the Death: I love
My Brain for the Invention, and thus
Confirm'd, dare truſt my Reſolution.
I did ſuſpect his Youth, and Beauty might
Win ſome Compaſſion when I came to kill him:
Or the Remebrance that he is my Kinſman,
Might thrill my Blood: Or ſomething in his Title,
Might give my Hand Repulſe, and ſtartle Nature:
But thus I have arm'd my ſelf againſt all pity,
That when I come to ſtrike, my Ponyard may
Through all his Charms as confidently wound him,
As thus I ſtab his Picture, and ſtare on it.
He ſmiles, he ſmiles upon me: I will dig
Thy wanton Eyes out, and ſupply the dark
And hollow Cells with two pitch burning Tapers:
Then place thee Porter in ſome Charnel Houſe,
To light the Coffins in.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Signior Florio deſires to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: This muſt retire again into my Cloſet: Admit him.

lg.l: He commends
His Service to your Lordſhip, and hath ſent—
Much ado he had to effect it:
He hopes his Grace will quickly ſign his Pardon.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I have a ſuit, my Lord.

lg.l: My Siſter would intreat your Honour
She may be admitted privately, and that
I may have Privilege to prepare her Chamber:
She does retain ſome modeſty, and wou'd not
Truſt every Servant with her Shame: Their Eyes
Are apt to inſtruct their Tongues.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I wo'not ſee her my ſelf, command what you deſire.

lg.l: I'll give directions inſtantly: Poor Lady,
This is the Duke's hot Blood, but Heaven convert him:
Follow me, good Florio.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: We are all bound to you.
sp.stage: Recorders. [Amidea diſcovered in a Bed, prepar'd by two Gentlewomen.
sp.p: 2. The laſt we e'er ſhall do my Lady.

lg.l: So, now you may return, it will become
Your modeſt Duties, not to enquire the Reaſon▪
Of this ſtrange ſervice, nor to publiſh what
Y'ave been commanded; let me look upon
My Siſter now, ſtill ſhe retains her Beauty.
Death has been kind to leave her all this ſweetneſs.
Thus in a Morning have I oft ſaluted
My Siſter in her Chamber, ſate upon
Her Bed, and talk'd of many harmleſs paſſages;
But now 'tis night, and a long night with her,
I ne'er ſhall ſee theſe Curtains drawn again,
Until we meet in Heaven. The Duke already▪
Call me no more thy Lord, but thy Companion,
I will not wear that Honour in my Title,
Shall not be thine. Who's that?
The readier for your paſtime.
She means to make a Night on't.
This ſhall declare thee to Poſterity
The beſt of Siſters—What of that? and is not▪
A Brother's Life▪ more precious than a Trifle?
I prithee do not ſigh▪ How many Ladies
Would be ambitious of thy place to night,
And thank his Highneſs? Yes, and Virgins too.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: He will deſerve ſome Office 'bout your Perſon.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: With what words ſhall I expreſs my joy?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I leave you, Sir, to action. Florio is ſoon diſmiſt.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: My Friend, thou ſhalt be near our boſom.

lg.l: All perfect, 'till this minute, I could never
Boaſt I was happy: All this World has not.
A Bleſſing to exchange; this World! 'tis Heaven,
And thus I take Poſſeſſion of my Saint:
A ſleep already? 'Twere great pity to
Diſturb her Dream; yet if her Soul be not
Tir'd with the body's weight, it muſt convey
Into her Slumbers, I wait here, and thus
Seal my Devotion—What Winter dwells
Upon this Lip? 'Twas no warm kiſs. I'll try
Agen—the Snow is not ſo cold, I have
Drank Ice, and felt a numbneſs ſpread through
My blood at once—ha! Let me examine
A little better; Amidea! ſhe is dead, ſhe is dead!
What horror doth invade me? Help, Lorenzo;
Murder, where is Lorenzo?
Some Traytor hid within the Chamber, ſee
My Amidea's dead.
Dead? 'Tis impoſſible;
Yet ſh'as a wound upon her breaſt.
Ha! wilt thou murder me, Lorenzo, Villain?
Oh, ſpare me to conſider; I would live
A little longer; Treaſon.
A little longer, ſay ye?
It was my duty to obey you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Let's make him ſure, my Lord.

lg.l: Oh ſpare me, I may live and pardon thee:
Thy Prince begs mercy from thee, that did never
Deny thee any thing; pity my poor Soul,
I have not prayed.
I could have wiſh'd you better prepar'd,
But let your Soul e'en take his chance.
No tear prevail? Oh, whither muſt I wander?
Thus Caeſar fell by Brutus. I ſhall tell
News to the World I go to, will not be
Believ'd, Lorenzo kill'd me.
I'll preſently put in ſecurity.
I am coming, Amidea, I am coming:
For thee, inhumane Murderer, expect
My blood ſhall flye to Heaven, and there inflam'd,
Hang a prodigious Meteor all thy life.
Oh I faint! Thou flattering World farewell: Let Princes gathe
My duſt into a Glaſs, and learn to ſpend
Their hour of State, that's all they have; for when
That's out, Time never turns the Glaſs again.
So, lay him beſide his Miſtreſs.
The Duke diſmiſt the Train came with him?
Run to Sciarrha, pray him come, and ſpeak wo' me;
Secure his paſſage to this Chamber, haſte.
He's dead, I'll truſt him now, and his Ghoſt too:
Fools ſtart at ſhadows, I'm in love with night,
And her Complexion.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: My Lord, he's come without your Summons.

lg.l: Already? leave us.
Welcome, let embraces
Chain us together▪ Noble Florio welcome:
But I muſt honour thy Great Soul.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: He's not ſtirring yet: Thou kil'dſt thy Siſter, didſt not?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: You cannot wake him, look you.

lg.l: And in his Death we two begin our Life
Of Greatneſs, and of Empire, nay, he's dead.
Now I pronounce, Sciarrha,
Thy Pardon, and to recompence thy loſs.
The ſhare of Florence, I'll but wear the Title,
The Power we'll divide.
I like this well:
You told a Tale once of a Commonwealth, and Liberty.
It was to gain a Faction
With diſcontented Perſons, a fine Trick
To make a Buzz of Reformation.
My ends are compaſs'd, Dam the Ribble Rabble.
Shall we Sweat for the People? Loſe our Breath
To get them fame?
I'll have it given out
The Duke did kill thy Siſter.
Having firſt raviſh'd her, he cannot be
Too hateful; it will dull the Examination
Of his own Death; or if that come to queſtion—
What if I ſay, I kill'd him in Revenge
Of Amidea? They will pity me.
Beſide, 'twill be in your power to pardon
Me altogether.

sp.speaker: Sci.
sp.p: The Devil wo'not leave us o'the ſuddain.

lg.l: Rare wit:
How haſtily he climbs the Precipice,
From whence one Fillup topples him to ruine:
We two ſhall live like Brothers.
Stay, we two—now I conſider better,
I have no mind to live at all—and you ſha'not,
I'll give you proof; if you but make a noiſe,
You gallop to the Devil.

sp.speaker: Sci.
sp.p: To Death inevitable. Brother be you Spectator only.

lg.l: Thank me, not Lorenzo, I'll not engage
His Innocence to blood, thy hands are white,
Preſerve 'em, Florio; and unleſs my arm
Grow feeble, do not interpoſe thy Sword I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: None to aſſiſt me? help, Petruchio, help.

div.stage: They fight, Enter Petruchio, who offering to run at Sciarrha, is intercepted by Florio, Petruchio, runs in crying help, Florio makes faſt the door.

lg.l: Reach thy jaws wider, Villain, cry out Murther,
Treaſon, any thing; hold—Oh.
I know not, ha? Yes, he has prick'd me ſomewhere,
But I'll make ſure of him▪ now muſt I follow:
I'll fight with him i'th' tother World—thy hand,
Florio. Farewell.
He's dead too, 'tis in vain for me to fly▪
Within. Break open the doors.

div.stage: Enter Pretruchio, Coſmo, Allonſo, Frederico, with Guard.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.p: I tremble, here is a heap of Tragedies.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: We muſt have an account from Florio.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: He can inform you beſt that brought you hither.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Lay hands upon Petruchio, diſarm him.

sp.speaker: Coſ.
sp.p: What blood is that upon his Sword? 'tis freſh▪

lg.l: Spare your fury, know
'Twas the beſt blood in Florence, I muſt quit
Young Florio; Lorenzo, and my ſelf,
Are only guilty of the Prince's Death▪
The Duke's Luſt:
There was no other way to ſave her Honour.
My Brother has reveng'd it here, but Fate
Deny'd him Triumph.
I never heard
Such killing Stories, but 'tis meet▪ we firſt
Settle the State; Coſmo, you are the next
Of Blood, to Challenge Florence.
Pray deferr
That 'till the Morning, drag that Murtherer
To Priſon; Florio, you muſt not expect
Your Liberty, 'till all things be examin'd.
Lorenzo, now I am above thy malice,
And will make ſatisfaction to Oriana.
'Tis a ſad Night, my Lords, by theſe you ſee
There is no ſtay in proud Mortality.
